title: Kweisi Mfume
added: Mfume has also credited boxing legend Muhammad Ali as being a major influence on his life.<ref name=mfumeali>https://baltimore.cbslocal.com/2016/06/06/former-naacp-president-kweisi-mfume-shares-his-memories-of-the-late-great-muhammad-ali/</ref> He first met Ali in 1977, when he still a local radio personality, and had a mock-bout with Ali at the Baltimore Civic Center to raise money for a local National of Islam mosque.<ref>https://digitaledition.baltimoresun.com/tribune/article_popover.aspx?guid=81ba47d0-de02-4079-bcc5-ccae11ca8058</ref>

title: Kweisi Mfume
added: Mfume has also credited boxing legend [[Muhammad Ali]] as being a major influence on his life.<ref name=mfumeali>https://baltimore.cbslocal.com/2016/06/06/former-naacp-president-kweisi-mfume-shares-his-memories-of-the-late-great-muhammad-ali/</ref> Mfume first met Ali in 1977, when he was still a local radio personality, and had a mock-boxing match with Ali at the Baltimore Civic Center to raise money for a local National of Islam mosque.<ref>https://digitaledition.baltimoresun.com/tribune/article_popover.aspx?guid=81ba47d0-de02-4079-bcc5-ccae11ca8058</ref> Despite his past affiliation with the Nation of Islam, Mfume eventually broke with the organization and publicly denounced the group's leader [[Louis Farrakhan]] in February 1994.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/05/us/farrakhan-is-bitterly-denounced-by-house-black-caucus-member.html</ref>

title: Kweisi Mfume
added: Mfume has also credited boxing legend [[Muhammad Ali]] as being a major influence on his life.<ref name=mfumeali>https://baltimore.cbslocal.com/2016/06/06/former-naacp-president-kweisi-mfume-shares-his-memories-of-the-late-great-muhammad-ali/</ref> Mfume first met Ali in 1977, when he was still a local radio personality, and had a mock-boxing match with Ali at the Baltimore Civic Center to raise money for a local National of Islam mosque.<ref>https://digitaledition.baltimoresun.com/tribune/article_popover.aspx?guid=81ba47d0-de02-4079-bcc5-ccae11ca8058</ref> Despite his past affiliation with the[[Nation of Islam]], Mfume eventually broke with the organization and publicly denounced the group's leader [[Louis Farrakhan]] in February 1994.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/05/us/farrakhan-is-bitterly-denounced-by-house-black-caucus-member.html</ref>

title: Kweisi Mfume
added: Mfume has also credited boxing legend [[Muhammad Ali]] as being a major influence on his life.<ref name=mfumeali>https://baltimore.cbslocal.com/2016/06/06/former-naacp-president-kweisi-mfume-shares-his-memories-of-the-late-great-muhammad-ali/</ref> Mfume first met Ali in 1977, when he was still a local radio personality, and had a mock-boxing match with Ali at the Baltimore Civic Center to raise money for a local National of Islam mosque.<ref>https://digitaledition.baltimoresun.com/tribune/article_popover.aspx?guid=81ba47d0-de02-4079-bcc5-ccae11ca8058</ref> Despite hispreviousaffiliation with the [[Nation of Islam]], Mfume eventually broke with the organization and publicly denounced the group's leader [[Louis Farrakhan]] in February 1994over the decision to keep an aide who had made controversial comments which appeared to be anti-Semitic.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/05/us/farrakhan-is-bitterly-denounced-by-house-black-caucus-member.html</ref><ref>https://www.baltimoresun.com/news/bs-xpm-1994-02-02-1994033019-story.html</ref>

title: Kweisi Mfume
added: Mfume has also credited boxing legend [[Muhammad Ali]] as being a major influence on his life.<ref name=mfumeali>https://baltimore.cbslocal.com/2016/06/06/former-naacp-president-kweisi-mfume-shares-his-memories-of-the-late-great-muhammad-ali/</ref> Mfume first met Ali in 1977, when he was still a local radio personality, and had a mock-boxing match with Ali at the Baltimore Civic Center to raise money for a local National of Islam mosque.<ref>https://digitaledition.baltimoresun.com/tribune/article_popover.aspx?guid=81ba47d0-de02-4079-bcc5-ccae11ca8058</ref> Despite his previous affiliation with the [[Nation of Islam]](NOI), Mfume eventually broke with the organization and publicly denounced the group's leader [[Louis Farrakhan]] in February 1994 over the decision to keep aideKhalid Abdul Muhammad,who had made controversial commentsin November 1993whichreferredtoJewsas "bloodsuckers."<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/05/us/farrakhan-is-bitterly-denounced-by-house-black-caucus-member.html</ref><ref>https://www.baltimoresun.com/news/bs-xpm-1994-02-02-1994033019-story.html</ref><ref>https://apnews.com/34c87c47402dbcbedfbcf19918f3ab92</ref> The day after Mfume's remarks, which were given at a press conference, Farrakhan removed Khalid as the NOI spokesman.<ref>https://library.cqpress.com/cqalmanac/document.php?id=cqal94-1102441</ref>

title: Kweisi Mfume
deleted: Despite running against the widow of his Congressional successor and predecessor [[Elijah Cummings]] in the Democratic Congressional primaries which were held in February and May 2020, it has been acknowledged that Mfume was in fact a friend of Cummings as well.<ref>https://www.baltimoresun.com/politics/bs-md-pol-mfume-sworn-in-20200505-36g7ub2bwvbqxdxv4beu7btl3e-story.html</ref><ref name=friendwins>https://www.baltimoresun.com/politics/elections/bs-md-pol-house-20200602-c4ec7kprf5d53flr5knkuj4jtu-story.html</ref> He had also delivered a eulogy at the funeral of Cummings in October 2019.<ref>https://www.wbaltv.com/article/kweisi-mfume-remembers-his-friend-elijah-cummings/29590689</ref><ref>https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/md-politics/maya-rockeymoore-cummings-questions-kweisi-mfumes-stories-about-her-late-husband/2020/05/11/d85f6a34-9395-11ea-9f5e-56d8239bf9ad_story.html</ref>

Mfume has also credited boxing legend [[Muhammad Ali]] as being a major influence on his life.<ref name=mfumeali>https://baltimore.cbslocal.com/2016/06/06/former-naacp-president-kweisi-mfume-shares-his-memories-of-the-late-great-muhammad-ali/</ref> Mfume first met Ali in 1977, when he was still a local radio personality, and had a mock-boxing match with Ali at the Baltimore Civic Center to raise money for a local National of Islam mosque.<ref>https://digitaledition.baltimoresun.com/tribune/article_popover.aspx?guid=81ba47d0-de02-4079-bcc5-ccae11ca8058</ref>

Despite his previous affiliation with the [[Nation of Islam]] (NOI), Mfume eventually broke with the organization and publicly denounced the group's leader [[Louis Farrakhan]] on February 2, 1994 over the decision to keep aide [[Khalid Abdul Muhammad]], who had made controversial comments in November 1993 which referred to Jews as "bloodsuckers of the black nation."<ref name=breakernoi /><ref name=breaknoi>https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/05/us/farrakhan-is-bitterly-denounced-by-house-black-caucus-member.html</ref><ref>https://www.baltimoresun.com/news/bs-xpm-1994-02-02-1994033019-story.html</ref><ref>https://apnews.com/34c87c47402dbcbedfbcf19918f3ab92</ref> In September 1993, two months before Khalid's remarks, Mfume invited Farakkan to address the annual legislative conference of [[Congressional Black Caucus]], which Mfume chaired.<ref name=breaknoi /> During the conference, Mfume announced that both the CBC and NOI would work together on strengthening the black community.<ref name=breaknoi /><ref name=breakernoi /> However, Brooklyn CBC member [[Major R. Owens]] acknowledged to the [[New York Times]] that Farrakhan had requested the invitation to speak at the CBC legislative conference beforehand and denied that the CBC had ever intended to formally approve the proposed NOI-CBC relationship, which Mfume described as a "sacred convenant."<ref name=breaknoi /><ref name=breakernoi /> The day after Mfume's remarks, which were given at a press conference, Farrakhan demoted Khalid and also removed him as the NOI spokesman.<ref name=breaknoi /><ref name=breakernoi>https://library.cqpress.com/cqalmanac/document.php?id=cqal94-1102441</ref>

title: Kweisi Mfume
added: Mfume is [[2020 United States House of Representatives elections in Maryland#District 7|running for re-election in the November 2020 race]].<ref name="candidacy" />
